Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for 2018 International Particle Accelerator Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for US students to participate in the primary annual international conference on accelerator science and its applications, the 9th International Particle Accelerator Conference (IPAC`18) to be held in Vancouver, Canada on April 29 - May 4, 2018. The IPACs are an annual series of conferences that rotate between the Americas, Europe, and Asia to highlight the science and engineering of major accelerator facilities, provide scientists with a forum for presenting results from research conducted using accelerators, and serve as a venue for describing new applications of accelerators. Accelerators and accelerator-driven light sources are burgeoning worldwide, offering new prospects not only for fundamental discovery science, but for medicine, biology, energy, environment, national security, and industry. This award will give many students the first opportunity of their scientific careers to be exposed to the breadth of this growing field of basic and applied research.

The award will be used to provide partial travel support for US students to attend the conference. The recipients of the travel support will be making presentations at the conference and will assist in conducting the conference. Attendance of 10 US students will be facilitated by the funds provided by this award. The conference will be an excellent opportunity for early career scientists to interact with more experienced researchers and their colleagues in the broader international scientific community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Particle Accelerator Conferences (IPAC) are an annual series of events held in different parts of the world. In addition to attracting eminent researchers in the field of particle accelerators, IPAC attracts vendors who display the latest accelerator technologies as well as prospecting for new ideas and people. The IPAC attracts graduate student participation through a competitive grant selection process whereby students are chosen using several criteria including: evaluating the significance of student research through the abstracts of contributed papers, letters of recommendations, and prior travel grant support, among others. Student travel grants to the conference are highly sought after and, especially for students trying to obtain international travel, one of the few means students have to attend the conference in the first place.

In 2018 three groups provided student travel support to IPAC: a grant of $20,000 which was provided by conference organizers at the TRIUMF laboratory, $12,000 from the United States National Science Foundation under Award 1830861, and $10,000 from the Treasurer of the Division of Physics of Beam of the American Physical Society. In particular, all of the award money from NSF was distributed to eight students to fund student travel to Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, April 29-May 4, 2018. The students attended 6 different universities in the United States, and one student was from a university without traditional strength in accelerator science. In total, twenty-five students were selected to receive travel grants from sixty-four applications to the conference for support from the “Americas” region, a 73% increase from 2017. The NSF travel grant funded roughly one-third of the total student travel. All twenty-five students made significant contributions to this conference, including two invited talks and one conference student presentation prize.
